1.breadcrumbs: SET UP » Set Up VS Code » Set Up VS Code
1.title: Set Up VS Code

10.body:
Before we make our game we need to set up the screen to display it! Make a screen that is 800 pixels wide and 600 pixels tall. This should be under the create constants comment For example: To make a screen that is 100 pixels wide and 200 pixels tall you could use this code WIDTH = 100
HEIGHT = 200
10.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 1: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Task 1.1: Create Game Screen » Step 1: Screen Size
10.title: Step 1: Screen Size

11.body: Now you need to tell Pygame to create a window of that size. Use the Pygame function pygame.display.set_mode()
11.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 1: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Task 1.1: Create Game Screen » Step 2: Set Up Your Game Window
11.title: Step 2: Set Up Your Game Window

12.body: You must complete Task 1.2 first BEFORE YOU CAN SEE A SCREEN WHEN YOU RUN YOUR PYGAME! Otherwise the window will crash immediately, AND YOU WON'T EVEN BE ABLE TO SEE IT!
12.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 1: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Task 1.1: Create Game Screen » YOU CANNOT SEE YOUR SCREEN YET
12.title: YOU CANNOT SEE YOUR SCREEN YET

13.body: Two variables for width and height A screen object created using Pygame and your variables
13.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 1: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Task 1.1: Create Game Screen » Checkpoint
13.title: Checkpoint

14.body: Now that you have set up your screen, you need to make sure the window stays open! Without a special piece of code, your game window will open for less than a second and then immediately close ! To keep your game running, you need a loop that keeps checking: Is the game still open? Did the player click the close (X) button?
14.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 1: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Task 1.2: Create Game Loop » Task 1.2: Create Game Loop
14.title: Task 1.2: Create Game Loop

15.body: First, you need a variable that ley Python check: Should the game keep running? Hint: Use a variable called **`running`** and set it to **True** at the start
15.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 1: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Task 1.2: Create Game Loop » Step 1: Create a "Running" Variable
15.title: Step 1: Create a "Running" Variable

16.body: Then you need a while loop. - It should say something like `while running:` - This means "**keep looping while the game is running**".
16.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 1: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Task 1.2: Create Game Loop » Step 2: Build a Loop
16.title: Step 2: Build a Loop

17.body:
Inside your while running: loop, you need to check what the player is doing . - Use `for event in pygame.event.get():`
- Go through all the events (like mouse clicks, window close, etc.)
- If the player close the game (event.type == pygame.QUIT`), you need to **stop the loop**!
17.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 1: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Task 1.2: Create Game Loop » Step 3: Handle Player Events
17.title: Step 3: Handle Player Events

18.body:
At the end of your while loop, refresh the screen: Hint:
- Use `pygame.display.update()`
18.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 1: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Task 1.2: Create Game Loop » Step 4: Update the Screen Every Frame
18.title: Step 4: Update the Screen Every Frame

19.body: No crashing! Your window should stay open until you click the X! You should see something like this: black game window
19.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 1: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Task 1.2: Create Game Loop » Checkpoints
19.title: Checkpoints

2.breadcrumbs: SET UP » Make Python File » Make Python File
2.title: Make Python File

20.body: Now it’s time to make your game look cooler by adding a background! Instead of just showing a black screen, let’s add an image behind everything.
20.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 1: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Task 1.3: Add Background Image » Task 1.3: Add Background Image
20.title: Task 1.3: Add Background Image

21.body: First you need to load the background image into your game. You can first save the image path as a variable : - Something like `background_image = "images/background/wooden_floor.jpeg"` - Then load it using `pygame.image.load(background_image)`
21.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 1: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Task 1.3: Add Background Image » Step 1: Load the Background Image
21.title: Step 1: Load the Background Image

22.body:
Sometimes your background image won't match your screen size exactly. You want to make sure the background fits the window! Hint:
- Use `pygame.transform.scale(...)`
- Resize the background to be `(screen_size_x, screen_size_y)`
22.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 1: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Task 1.3: Add Background Image » Step 3: Scale the Background Image
22.title: Step 3: Scale the Background Image

23.body: Finally, draw the background onto the screen. ``Hint: Use screen.blit(...) You want the background at the top-left corner (0, 0) --- # Checkpoints - [ ] A `background_image` variable (path to the image) - [ ] A `background` variable (the scaled loaded image) - [ ] A `screen.blit(variable, coordinate)` line inside your `while running:` loop - [ ] A background showing up instead of a black screen!
23.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 1: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Task 1.3: Add Background Image » Step 4: Blit the Background onto the Screen
23.title: Step 4: Blit the Background onto the Screen

24.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 1: SET UP YOUR GAME SCREEN » Task 1.4: Add Icon and Game Title » Task 1.4: Add Icon and Game Title
24.title: Task 1.4: Add Icon and Game Title

25.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » GAME BASICS » Task 2: GAME BASICS
25.title: Task 2: GAME BASICS

26.body: Your task is to create a player class with the following properties name image sprite position_x position_y
26.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » GAME BASICS » Create a player class » Task 2.1 Create a player class
26.title: Task 2.1 Create a player class

27.body: Your task is to create an instance of the player class. Hint: something = ClassName() Doing so will call the __init__(self, ...) method of the class. Now, thinking back to yesterday, how might we access the variables of this class?
27.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » GAME BASICS » Create an instance of player » Task 2.2: Create an instance of player
27.title: Task 2.2: Create an instance of player

28.body: Under the player method, we need to create a draw method(). How might we create a method inside a class? If you are stuck have a read here . Perhaps the screen.blit(...) function could be useful... Now, in order for the player position to be updated very often, where would we call this draw method?
28.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » GAME BASICS » Create the draw method » Task 2.3: Create the draw method
28.title: Task 2.3: Create the draw method

29.body: Your task is to create the move method.
29.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » GAME BASICS » Create the move method » Task 2.4: Create the move method
29.title: Task 2.4: Create the move method

3.breadcrumbs: SET UP » Import Pygame » Import Pygame
3.title: Import Pygame

30.body:
First, you need to find whether a certain key is being pressed or not. Similar to yesterday, we can use a function called pygame.key.get_pressed() . Hint: This returns a list of booleans.
For example, the return value may look something like this -> [False, False, False, False, True, False, False] How might we check whether the 7th key is pressed?
30.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » GAME BASICS » Create the move method » Task 2.4.1
30.title: Task 2.4.1

31.body:
Secondly, we need to update the position_x and position_y variables of our player according to what key was pressed. For example, something like if w is pressed move up
else if a is pressed move left
else if s is pressed move down
else move right
31.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » GAME BASICS » Create the move method » Task 2.4.2
31.title: Task 2.4.2

32.body: Add player.move() and player.draw() to the game loop.
32.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » GAME BASICS » Create the move method » Task 2.4.3
32.title: Task 2.4.3

33.body: We’re going to fix the trailing images issue by re-drawing the background to the screen every time the game loops. Draw the background to the screen again inside the game loop before drawing the bird. That fixed it!
33.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » GAME BASICS » Fix duplicating Poco » Task 2.5: Fix duplicating Poco
33.title: Task 2.5: Fix duplicating Poco

34.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 3: OTHER ASSETS » Task 3: OTHER ASSETS
34.title: Task 3: OTHER ASSETS

35.body: In this task, you will create a Food class that acts as a blueprint for the food items (or anything else!) in your game. Every Food will have: A name An image A sprite A position on the screen
35.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 3: OTHER ASSETS » Task 3.1: Create a Food Class » Task 3.1: Create a Food Class
35.title: Task 3.1: Create a Food Class

36.body:
Start by creating a new class called Food. Hint:
- Remember to use the `class` keyword.
- Your class name should start with a **capital letter**. Example: class Food:
36.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 3: OTHER ASSETS » Task 3.1: Create a Food Class » Step 1: Define the Food Class
36.title: Step 1: Define the Food Class

37.body:
Inside your Food class, create a special function called __init__. Hints:
- Use the `def` keyword to define the method.
- The `__init__` method should accept **4 inputs**: - `name` - `image` - `position_x` - `position_y`
- Save each of these inputs into the object using `self.` This means: The food remembers its name The food knows where it appears The food remembers which image to load
37.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 3: OTHER ASSETS » Task 3.1: Create a Food Class » Step 2: Create the __init__() Method
37.title: Step 2: Create the __init__() Method

38.body:
Still inside your __init__() method, set a default size for your food. Hint:
- Create a new variable for size.
- Use a tuple like `(50, 50)` for width and height.
- Save it inside the object using `self.size`.
38.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 3: OTHER ASSETS » Task 3.1: Create a Food Class » Step 3: Set a Default Size
38.title: Step 3: Set a Default Size

39.body:
Still inside the __init__() method: Hints:
- Load the image file using Pygame's `image load` function.
- Scale the loaded image to the correct size using Pygame's `transform scale` function.
- Save the final scaled image into the object (e.g., `self.sprite`). This way, every food item will have: A properly loaded picture A size that fits the screen
39.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 3: OTHER ASSETS » Task 3.1: Create a Food Class » Step 4: Load and Scale the Sprite
39.title: Step 4: Load and Scale the Sprite

40.body: A Food class (or a class of things you want to have) An __init__() method that: Saves the name, image, and position Sets a default size Loads and scales the sprite A ready-to-use object for your game!
40.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 3: OTHER ASSETS » Task 3.1: Create a Food Class » Checkpoints
40.title: Checkpoints

41.body: Now that we have a Food class ready, it's time to create a dictionary to store all the different food items! A dictionary will let you: Store multiple foods easily Access their images and positions Organise your game's world neatly
41.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 3: OTHER ASSETS » Task 3.2: Create a Food Dictionary » Task 3.2: Create a Food Dictionary
41.title: Task 3.2: Create a Food Dictionary

42.body:
Create a dictionary called foods, This dictionary will hold all the food items you want to appear in your game. Hint:
- Use curly braces `{}` to create a dictionary.
- Save it in your main code **before** your game loop starts.
42.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 3: OTHER ASSETS » Task 3.2: Create a Food Dictionary » Step 1: Create an Empty Dictionary
42.title: Step 1: Create an Empty Dictionary

43.body: Inside your dictionary, add entries for each food you want! Each key should be the name of the food (like "banana", "grapes", etc.). Each value should be a list that contains: The path to the image file The x position The y position ```python "food name": ["path/to/image.png", x_position, y_position] ```
43.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 3: OTHER ASSETS » Task 3.2: Create a Food Dictionary » Step 2: Add Food Items into the Dictionary
43.title: Step 2: Add Food Items into the Dictionary

44.body: Now that you have a dictionary of food items, it's time to create real Food objects from that dictionary! We’ll create a list of active foods that can be drawn onto the screen later.
44.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 3: OTHER ASSETS » Task 3.4: Initialise Active Foods List » Task 3.3: Initialise Active Foods List
44.title: Task 3.3: Initialise Active Foods List

45.body:
First, create a new empty list called active_foods, This list will store all the Food objects you create. Hint:
- Use square brackets `[]` to create an empty list.
- Save this list somewhere **before your game loop starts**.
45.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 3: OTHER ASSETS » Task 3.4: Initialise Active Foods List » Step 1: Create an Empty List
45.title: Step 1: Create an Empty List

46.body:
Now write a for loop that goes through every item in your foods dictionary. In each loop, you will create a new Food object! - Use `.items()` to loop through both the **key** and **value**.
- The key will be the **name** of the food.
- The value will be a list containing: - `[image path, x position, y position]`
46.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 3: OTHER ASSETS » Task 3.4: Initialise Active Foods List » Step 2: Loop Over Your Foods Dictionary
46.title: Step 2: Loop Over Your Foods Dictionary

47.body:
Inside your loop: Create a new Food object. Give it the correct name , image , position_x , and position_y . Add the new Food object into the active_foods list. Hint:
- Use the key and value pieces carefully! - `key` -> name - `value[0]` -> image path - `value[1]` -> x position - `value[2]` -> y position
47.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 3: OTHER ASSETS » Task 3.4: Initialise Active Foods List » Step 3: Create a New Food Object for Each Item
47.title: Step 3: Create a New Food Object for Each Item

48.body: An empty active_foods list created A loop that: Goes through every food in your dictionary Creates a Food object Adds it into the active_foods list
48.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 3: OTHER ASSETS » Task 3.4: Initialise Active Foods List » Checkpoints
48.title: Checkpoints

49.body: Now that you have your Food objects ready, we need a way to draw them onto the screen! We will add a draw() method inside the Food class, so each food knows how to draw itself .
49.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 3: OTHER ASSETS » Task 3.5: Create Food Draw Method » Task 3.4: Create Food Draw Method
49.title: Task 3.4: Create Food Draw Method

5.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 0: SET UP » Task 0: SET UP
5.title: Task 0: SET UP

50.body:
Inside your Food class, create a new method called draw. This method won’t take any arguments (only self). This method will draw the food onto the screen. Hint:
- Use the `def` keyword.
- It should be written **inside** your Food class (at the same indentation level as `__init__()`).
50.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 3: OTHER ASSETS » Task 3.5: Create Food Draw Method » Step 1: Define a New Method Called draw()
50.title: Step 1: Define a New Method Called draw()

51.body:
Inside your draw() method: Hint:
- Use `screen.blit(...)` to draw.
- The first thing you want to draw is the **sprite** (image).
- The position to draw at is `(position_x, position_y)`.
51.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 3: OTHER ASSETS » Task 3.5: Create Food Draw Method » Step 2: Draw the Sprite Onto the Screen
51.title: Step 2: Draw the Sprite Onto the Screen

52.body: A draw() method inside your Food class which knows how to: Draw the sprite And place it at the correct position
52.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 3: OTHER ASSETS » Task 3.5: Create Food Draw Method » Checkpoints
52.title: Checkpoints

53.body: Now that each Food knows how to draw itself, it's time to actually draw all the food onto your game window during the game! You will loop through all active foods inside your while running: game loop.
53.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 3: OTHER ASSETS » Task 3.6: Draw Active Foods in Game Loop » Task 3.5: Draw Active Foods in Game Loop
53.title: Task 3.5: Draw Active Foods in Game Loop

54.body: Create a for loop inside your while running: loop which loop over the active_foods list. In each loop call the draw() method on the food to draw it on screen.
54.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 3: OTHER ASSETS » Task 3.6: Draw Active Foods in Game Loop » Step 1: Loop Over active_foods
54.title: Step 1: Loop Over active_foods

55.body: Inside the for loop: use player's method to check for interaction with the food. call the food’s .draw() method.
55.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 3: OTHER ASSETS » Task 3.6: Draw Active Foods in Game Loop » Step 2: Drawing and Interaction
55.title: Step 2: Drawing and Interaction

56.body: A for loop inside the main game loop You can interact with the food Draw the food onto the screen All your food are visible
56.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » Task 3: OTHER ASSETS » Task 3.6: Draw Active Foods in Game Loop » Checklist
56.title: Checklist

57.body: Goal: Detect whether the player is colliding with any of the food.
57.title: Task 4 Collision

58.body:
Create an extra property in the player and food class. Use the .get_rect().move() function to create a rectangle that moves with the class' sprite. Create a method called update(self) in the player class. Copy the property you just wrote into this method. Call the player update method in the main game loop, just underneath player.draw() # sprite.get_rect() creates a rectangle the size of the image
# .move() moves whatever it's attached to to an x and y coordinate
self.hitbox = self.sprite.get_rect().move(self.position_x, self.position_y)
58.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » COLLISION » Creating hitboxes » Task 4.1 Create a hitbox for both the players and the foods
58.title: Task 4.1 Create a hitbox for both the players and the foods

59.body:
Create a property called interact_foods(self, food) in the food class Use the colliderect to check whether the rectangular hitboxes are colliding If they are colliding, remove food from the active_foods list # Collision is True is the hitboxes are colliding and False if not
collision = self.hitbox.colliderect(food.hitbox)
59.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » COLLISION » Detecting collision » Task 4.1 Create a hitbox for both the players and the foods
59.title: Task 4.1 Create a hitbox for both the players and the foods
